text:
When we started from zero, people said:
‘Play the algorithm. Chase views.’

We stuck with chasing values.

When we hit 100K, people said:
‘Follow trends. Do what’s viral.’

We stuck with educating people.

At 1 million, they said:
‘Sensationalise. Make noise.’

We stuck with making sense.

At 10 million, people said:
‘Create drama. That’s what sells.’

We stuck with creating dreams.

From day one, we didn’t pick the easy path.
We picked the one that felt right.

And that’s why you, our audience, stuck with us.
Because what we built was never just a podcast.
It was a shared dream.

I learn to figure out life. And you learn with me.

And that story of building ambitions, chasing dreams, is why we’re announcing this partnership with ASUS as their brand ambassador.

We are coming together because we believe in making you realise the ambition inside you.

We have always believed in chasing your dreams, and ASUS helps in providing those tools that can help people turn their dreams into results.

It’s not just a partnership, it’s a shared commitment to empower Indian professionals and entrepreneurs.
What is that one thing you want to change about yourself to get better? And why?

You can’t always see leadership qualities in how people work.  Sometimes they come out in different settings. 

So a few weeks back, the whole Figuring Out team went to Lonavala for an offsite. 

We had sessions and activities for self-reflection, goal alignment, and what’s in store for the future of Figuring Out. 

And we also had games, team bonding activities, and just a whole lot of fun. 

The whole team was divided into 4 teams. 
And each team had a leader, a cool name, and a song. 
(my team’s name was Hunters, please don’t ask why or how)

There were a variety of tasks that each team had to do to win points.  A dance competition, cricket, artistic games, and more.

I noticed how every single task brought out a new kind of leader.

One person owned the choreography.
Another stepped up for captaincy in cricket.
Someone else took the pen during creative tasks.

No one was told to lead. No one was ‘assigned’ a role.
They just did it. Naturally. Quietly. Confidently.

It made me realise how their leadership qualities came out in different settings. 

They may not have shown the same in the office. 
Different personalities shine in different situations.

A lot of you might disagree with me on this, but talent is overrated. 

It’s not all that you make it seem.

You see someone doing better than you and immediately go,
‘They’re just more talented than me.’ 
And maybe they are.

But that’s not the problem. The real problem is you think that’s the end of the story.

It’s not.

You can outwork someone more talented. It’ll be harder, sure.
You’ll probably have to put in 3x the effort. Maybe more.
But it’s doable. And in the long run, it won’t even matter.

Because when you’re consistent, when you keep showing up, keep getting better, keep putting in the hours, you build something meaningful, and then talent or not, it makes no difference.

If you’ve been outworking everyone from day one, you’ve already built the muscle for it.

You know how to take hits and keep going. That’s what actually takes you far.

It’s not sexy. It’s not glamorous.
But it works.

You don’t need to be the most gifted in the room. You just need to be the one who doesn’t stop

I’ve said this at least 10 times on the podcast,

I’m obsessed with human psychology.

Why people do what they do. What drives them.
What they don’t even realise they’re doing.
It fascinates me. Every single time.

And the thing is, it really helps you in business.
If you understand what people want and why they want it, you figure out how to give it to them.

Even the daily behaviours teach you something or the other. 
There’s always a pattern. A reason. A story behind the action

‘Balance’ is one of the biggest lies sold to our generation.

Everyone’s trying to give 50-50 to everything: work, relationships, health, fun. And then wondering why nothing’s actually moving.

It doesn’t work like that.
You don’t build anything meaningful by dividing your energy equally every day.

You prioritise. You maximise.
One thing at a time.

If work needs you right now, go all in.
Be obsessed. Work like a maniac.
Don’t guilt yourself over it.

But if your relationships are falling apart and that matters to you, then yes, take a little step back from the hustle. Fix it. Also, no guilt.

Balance isn’t 50-50. 
Balance isn’t about splitting everything evenly.

It’s about knowing what matters most right now and giving it your all.

Then once that’s stable, you optimise the rest.

The reason most people feel burnt out and stuck is that they are trying to be everything, everywhere, all at once.

Pick what matters.
Max it out. Then move.

If your own work doesn’t make you respect yourself,
nothing anyone says about you will ever feel enough.

Because deep down, you’ll know.
You’ll know you’re not working the way you say you are.

A lot of people talk big about ambition, goals, building something massive. But when you look at their actions the work doesn’t match the volume of their voice.

And that gap creates self-doubt, inferiority, insecurities.
Then it doesn’t matter how much external validation you get.
Compliments, praise, likes, followers, it all feels fake.

Because when you don’t respect your own work, no amount of praise will fix that.

You know you’re not actually doing the hard part.
And that eats at you. Quietly. Constantly.

You’ll start to feel small in front of people.
You’ll question yourself in every room.

Self-respect isn’t just a mindset.
It’s based on evidence.

You earn it by doing what you said you would do.
By becoming the person your words claim to be.

And if you keep skipping that part, you’re never going to feel good enough.

I work like there’s no tomorrow. I have an urgency to do stuff. 

But not everyone works like me. 
Not everyone should.

You can’t judge everyone by your pace, your methods, or your goals.

You can’t have the same bar for everyone.
You can’t see them with the same lens.

One person might be going for speed.
Another for balance.
One is chasing freedom.
Another is feeding a family.

Context changes everything. 

So before you label someone as lazy, slow, or lacking ambition, know their goals, personal problems, and circumstances. 

Ask yourself if you’re seeing the full picture.
Chances are, you’re not.

Not everyone’s playing the same game.

Respect that and you’ll waste a lot less time judging people who were never supposed to move like you in the first place.

I don’t need to win at everything. And I’m okay with that.

You can dress better than me. Write better than me.
Be better at socialising, marketing, whatever.

That doesn’t bother me.
Because I know what game I’m playing.

When it comes to my work, my podcast, my content, the things I’m building every day, that’s where I won't let myself lose.

That’s the space I’m willing to outwork anyone.

People will always be better than you at something.
Let them.

You don’t have to win at everything.
You just have to make sure no one can beat you at your thing.

Be okay with losing 99 battles if it means you win the one that actually matters to you.

In a startup, your oldest people should get the first shot at leadership.

They were there when no one knew the brand.
When things were messy, uncertain, and unglamorous.

They’ve seen how things were built.
They’ve made decisions when there were no playbooks.

They didn’t just do their job, they built the job with you.
And they know the business inside out.

So when a leadership role opens up, they deserve the first opportunity.

You give them a chance to step up.
And if they can handle it, great. 
They grow with the company.

But if they can’t, and that will happen too, you do what’s needed.
You bring in someone who can take things forward. 
Because the business has to grow, no matter what.

But it’s on you to give people who helped build your business a fair chance to grow with it.

Founders are losing in the business game because they are so busy making everyone around them happy.

People-pleasing is one of the most dangerous habits I’ve seen in founders, business owners.

And they hide it behind the excuse of being ‘democratic.’

Democracy does not mean you have to make every person happy. 

It means that the majority is aligned, and you keep moving.

The moment you start listening to every opinion, suggestion, or complaint, you lose speed, things become unclear, and your leadership is questioned. 

At the start, speed is everything.
And if every decision needs to make everyone happy, you’ll never be able to move forward. 

Democracy can help your business, but people pleasing will only damage it.

If you can’t control your emotions, people will control you. Always.

People lose business, relationships, and respect just because they couldn’t control a reaction in one heated moment.

It’s easy to react.
To snap. To argue. To prove a point.

But every time you react without thinking, you hand over control to the other person, the situation, the chaos.

The most dangerous people are the ones who stay calm even when disrespected.

Power is not in being the loudest in the room. 
It’s in knowing you could respond, but choosing not to. 

Why do you have the need to prove anything to anyone?
Be clear on what deserves your energy and what doesn’t.

When you don’t react, people stop trying to control you.
You stop playing their game.

This is why you are not able to get success quickly-

Everyone wants success right now.
No one wants to grind for years.

It’s always, ‘What’s the shortcut?’ ‘What’s the hack?’

Look, there’s no substitute for work.
Your work ethic should match the ambition that comes out of your mouth.

It’s easy to say you want to build something big.
To talk about goals, vision, and success.

But big dreams don’t mean sh*t without big discipline.

You don’t get what you want.
You get what you’re willing to show up for, every single day.

No shortcuts. No hacks. Just showing up.

That’s the only thing that separates those who make it and those who don’t

Startups don’t die because they run out of money.
They die because they try to do too much.

Founders think they need to chase every shiny thing.
New features. New markets. New partnerships.

But you can’t win 10 races at once.
You’ll just lose all of them.

Amazon sold only books for 2 years.
Instagram was just photo filters when it launched.

Every great company started by doing one boring thing obsessively well.

Focus is how you earn the right to grow.

Do the one thing that’ll actually move the needle.
Kill the rest

You’re not burnt out because you’re tired.
You’re burnt out because you’re bored.

Burnout doesn’t happen after a long day of doing something you love.

That’s just you being exhausted. 
You rest, and the next day you're back at it.

Real burnout happens when you’re stuck doing things you didn’t want to do in the first place.

Things that don’t excite you.
Things that don’t appeal to you.
Meetings you didn't need to be in.
Emails that didn't need you to be looped in. 
Sitting on a chair all day and working because you have to.

That’s what drains you.
Not creating. Not building. Not solving.

Some people work long hours and still show up excited the next morning. And some work 2 hours and feel dead inside. 

The difference is not the hours. It’s the purpose behind them.

If you’re feeling burnt out, ask yourself:
Is this actually hard work? Or is this just work I don't like?

Burnout isn’t about doing too much.
It’s about doing too little of what actually matters.

Most founders are control freaks.
That’s why their company never grows beyond them.

In the beginning, you do everything: sales, content, hiring, even packing boxes if you have to.

But if you're still doing it all after a couple of years, you’re not building a business. You’re just building yourself a job.

Delegation feels scary because you think no one can do it like you.
 
Look, you won't know how to do everything. You hire people because they can do it better.

You bring in people with sharper skills, different perspectives, and ideas you’d never think of.

And that’s what actually pushes the business forward.

The faster you learn to let go, the faster your company learns to grow.

I don’t have a college degree. 

Did I drop out? 
What happened? 
Why didn’t I complete it?

That’s a story for another time. 
For now, I don’t have a degree, and I don’t check if my team does either. 

Yesterday, I was talking to a couple of people from my team, and the topic of college came up. That’s when it hit me how little importance we give to formal education. 

We check what you can do and your attitude towards learning.
We want pure skill and hunger to learn, that’s it.

I’m not saying you should drop out or not go for that master’s, but that is not the only way to do things. 

Technology has advanced so much, you have the world at your fingertips. 

Instead of sitting around and waiting for someone to come and teach you what you want to do in life, learn to take things into your own hands. 

Yes, do go to college. 
But it’s not the college’s responsibility to make a career for you.

You need to upskill yourself.

If you want to make a lot of money, you’ll have to compromise your morals.

This is something I used to believe when I was a little kid. 

You know how the saying goes, 
'Paise kam hain, par chain ki neend hai.'
(Money might be less, but at least I sleep peacefully.)

Because it was assumed that rich people had gained all that success and wealth by shortcuts and wrongdoings.

But I was so wrong. 

The more I worked, the more I realised you don’t have to bend your morals to win.

You can play fair.
Stick to your values.
Stay within the system.
And still get everything you have ever wanted.

All it takes is unshakable belief, hard work, the right team, and just a little bit of luck. 

Don’t go the wrong way when you can get everything by staying on the right path. 

Yes, it’ll take a little extra work and time, but at least 'chain ki neend' won’t be compromised.

You know how you feel defeated when failure hits you? 
Well, it’s the best thing that can happen to you. 

This is not some ‘you learn from your failures’ bullsh*t. 
You do learn, but learning isn’t exclusive to failing.

When you do something and succeed, you set a benchmark. 

Now, to anything to work for you, it either reaches that benchmark or goes beyond. 

And because you know it worked, you will be scared to change even a little thing.

Copy and paste becomes the norm. 

Failure, on the other hand, works the opposite. 
You fail, fail, fail and then anything, even with a little bit of improvement, will work. 

You don’t have a set mould. There are no expectations. 
You have the freedom to go do whatever you want and watch it work for you. 

It gives you wings to explore. 
Do things you couldn’t when the benchmark held you back from experimenting.

I’ve never liked reading. Still don’t.

But I read every single day.
Because I’m curious, I want to learn.

Because there’s too much stuff in the world that you can never get enough of. 

Look, nobody likes doing the boring stuff. 
Everyone wants to be smart, successful, ahead of the game.

But no one wants to do the hard, slow stuff that gets you there.

Reading isn’t glamorous.
But it’s the most boring habits that create long-term success.

You don’t read one book and suddenly know it all.
You read one, and it shows you how much you don’t know.

Then you read more books, articles, blogs, whatever you can find.

There’s too much happening in the world.
Too many smart people outworking, outlearning, outpacing you.

And if you’re not growing, you’re falling behind. 
Silently. Slowly. Then suddenly.

From the outside, success looks effortless.
But in reality, it’s just a bunch of ordinary habits repeated daily.
